Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare is £9 to Brindisi. The cobined Sea and special train fare has been reduced to £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles. During the Monsoon season the express streamer usually reaches Brindisi on Thursday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 pm and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 pm on Saturday.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.

MONDAY, AUGUST 14, 1905.

div.head: OUR NEXT GOVERNMENT’S FOREIGN POLICY.
div.p: If all Radical leaders spoke with the knowledge and moderation employed by Sir Charles Dilke, when discussing foreign affairs, their patriotism would be much more in evidence than has, unfortunately, been the case of late. Lord E. Fitzmaurice also deserves praise for his frank acceptance of the principle that continuity of policy in our relations with other Powers should be, and must be, strictly observed. It is most refreshing and stimulating to have these utterances from representative Radicals after the constant wavering of the Opposition chief. There is the more likelihood that Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman would, if promoted to the Premiership, come to the sound conclusion that instability of purpose in directing the external affairs of the greatest and most widespread Empire in the world would inevitably replace Great Britain in that position of isolation which, not so long ago, crippled her influence among the nations. The proposal to renew our treaty of alliance with Japan, in more extended form, cannot be finally judged on its merits until the de-tails are made known in full. But it is a long step towards its adoption that the bare ‘idea of this new concordat should have re-ceived general approval recently gp both sides

of the House. It is manifest that owing to the changes in the balance of Asiatic power and influence resulting from the Russo-Japanese conflict, the whole political situation in the Far East has completely altered. Up to the present the alliance has merely bound Great Britain to help the insular Power, should any other nation interfere in the war on the side of Russia. That was a sufficient object to aim at when hostilities began, and the world owes to it the isolation of both combatants in a comparatively narrow area. But there are other points of danger in Asia to the allies-points where conflict would be inevitable were either to break away from the league of peace. It is, therefore, a perfectly sound and statesmanlike policy on the part of His Majesty's Ministers to renew the agreement in such an enlarged shape as may safeguard the whole of Asia from the devastations of war.

It is obvious that the Russian Government would be much less likely to break the peace it aware that Japan was closely associated with Great Britain in its maintenance against all disturbers. There is a moral force as well as a military in alliances: here in Europe the Dual Alliance has continuously operated, ever since it came into being, as a check on the possible aggressiveness of the Triple Allianoe directed from Berlin Chauvinists at St Petersburg and Moscow would think, we may make sure, once, and twioe, about a march to the Indus if that suicidal endeavour would bring upon their over-grown Empire a Japanese invasion of Eastern Siberia. It is this restrictive force on pugnacious proclivities which lends so much value to the enlargement of the present treaty; for one thing, it would render that farther partition of China which is believed to find favor in august quarters at Berlin, well-nigh impracticable. For the Celestial Empire, now so weak and impotent, could then rely on receiving naval and military assistance from the two most powerful fighting nations in Asia; and, with that support, could safely afford to smile at the ‘mailed fist.”

As to Africa although it would be premature regard all difficulties in the Congo State, dne to bad administration, as ended, improvements are being introduced generally, while the Congo Government has unreservedly undertaken to give effect to the report of the investigating Commission as soon as it is rendered. It is not unnatural that British philanthropists should display impatience at the secrecy which characterised the inquiry for a time. Bat now that it is moving more quickly in the required direction it would be a mistake on their part to goad such a very willing horse as the present Cabinet It is much the same in the case of Turkey. The Government is doing all in its power to influence the Sultan to introduce administrative and financial reforms without further delay, but Abdul Hamid still shows marked reluctance to be hurried along a path he does not desire to tread. It may be hoped, however, that the slumberous air of Yildiz Kiosk will be wholesomely stirred by the solemn warning which fell from Lord -Percy lately. Without any mincing of phrases, he counselled the Turkish Government to reform its method of rule in Macedonia and else- where, lest “His Majesty’s Government should have to reconsider their attitude.” The Saltan is sufficiently sagacious to place the right construction on this plain intimation, especially as it represents the united resolve of all the Great Powers. Even Germany, so reluctant to give him offence, has at last come into line with the rest of Europe on the burning question of financial reform and its collaterals, and we imagine that here at all events the coming Radical Government is certain to imitate its predecessors in office. It is only over South African matters that a certain uneasiness prevails as to “C. B.’s” intentions, but we doubt whether any revolutionary changes are likely to be made by a Cabinet that is not likely to be supported by a large and united majority.

div.head: PEACE CONFERENCE.
DISCUSSION OF FIRST CLAUSE.
IMPORTANT POINTS UNDECIDED.
div.p: Portsmouth (N.H.), August 12. It is cod firmed that the Russian reply rejects the payment of an indemnity, and the cession of territory, it declares that Russia is not vanquished. She has suffered reverses, but is not obliged to accept peace at any cost. It throws the responsibility for the war on Japan.
( Reuter.)

Portsmouth (U.S.A.), August 12. The peace conference has met . twice. The Russians have given their answer. The Japanese will meet to morrow to consider the answer. Signs point to an amelioration of the situation.
(Havas)
New York, August 12. The newspapers assert that in the case of the negotiations breaking down, Marshal Oya-ma will attack General Linievitch.
Havas.)
St. Petersburg, August 12. The newspapers and public opinion are unanimous in considering the Japanese conditions outrageous.
{Havas)

Portsmouth (N.H.), August 13. The discussion of the first clause of the peace conditions lasted all yesterday afternoon and was then adjourned, but the two main points of the negotiations, viz., the indemnity and the cession of Saghalien have been left temporarily in abeyance.
(Reuter).
Portsmouth (U.S.A.), August 13. The peace conference did not meet to-day. it has adjourned until to-morrow.
(Havas.)
THE BLACK SEA MUTINEERS.
LIGHT SENTENCES.

St. Petersburg, August 13. The sentences on the Black Sea mutineers are unexpectedly light, as the authorities fear to take extreme measures. Fifteen have been acquitted, five sentenced to penal servitude for life, and the rest to lighter punishment.
FRANCE AND ENGLAND.
PARLIAMENTARY LUNCHEON TO FLEET.

London, August 12. At the Parliamentary luncheon to the French officer at Westminster Hall, Mr. Balfour said that Great Britain and France have too Often been divided, but that for the future their interests throughout the world are identical.
(Reuter)

London, August 12. The officers of the French fleet have been entertained to luncheon by Parliament The Chancellor, the Speaker, Mr. Balfour, and Admiral Caillard drank to the perpetual friendship of the two countries amidst enthusiastic cheering.
(Havas.)
FAMINE IN SOUTHERN SPAIN.
PEASANTS RAIDING FARMS.

Madrid, August 12. The famine in Southern Spain is getting worse daily. Bands of peasants ate killing flocks, and attacking farms, the inmates of which are defending themselves with fire-arms The governor of Cadiz has telegraphed that he cannot be responsible for the rural peace,
EARTHQUAKE AT MACAO.
Macao, August 12. There have been continuous earthquake shocks for nine hours. Crowds of people are filling the parks, and steamers are leaving for Hong-Kong crammed with passengers.
THE FRENCH ARMY.

Paris, August 13. M. Loubet, in making a speech at vill- neuve-sur Rhone, said that the army, inacces sible to pernicious doctrines, would defend the flag in case of necessity; it was the best gua rantee of peace.
(Havas.)
YELLOW FEVER IN AMERICA.
New Orleans, August 13. The yellow fever here is spreading in the most serious manner. 107 fresh cases and 9 deaths took place yesterday.
(Reuter).
CURE FOR LEPROSY DISCOVERED

Manila, August 13. It is believed that the Board of Health has discovered a cure for leprosy by means of Rontgen- rays. Twenty-five cases have bee treated for six months, six of which are apparently cured, whilst all have improved.
(Reuter.)

THE Plague. — Twenty cases of bubonic plague were notified in Egypt during the week ending Saturday last. Eighteen of these oc-cur ed at Alexandria and two at "Port Said. | Since January 1 there have in all been 221 cases, as compared with 765 during the correspond- ing period last year. Three deaths occurred in Alexandria on Saturday and one yesterday.

Street Accidents.—A cyclist who was riding along Minetlel Bassal-street on Sunday afternoon ran into an Italian woman, who was knocked down, and sustained severe injuries to her head. Another accident occurred at the Customs the same afternoon, a Greek woman being run over by a native who was riding on horseback; and who was also severely injured.

cattle PLAGUE. During the week ending last Saturday nine deaths from cattle plague were reported in Egypt, all of which occurred at kalionb. The number of deaths during the corresponding period last year was 584. The total number of deaths, since the commencement of the epidemic is to 147,433, dis-tributied as follows : — Gouvernorats, 895 ; Lower Egypt 54,291 ; Upper Egypt 92,247:

TRAMCAR Accident.—A Sudanese, Suroor Abdulla by name, belonging to the Coastguards service, Alexandria, in dismounting from a tram, fell, and received injuries sufficiently severe to necessitate his removal to hospital. The man asserts that the conductor started the tram before he had dismounted, and so caused him to be thrown off by the jerk, whilst the conductor denies having done so, and says that the man sustained his injuries by getting off the tram whilst in motion, contrary to the regulations. An inquirt into the matter is being made by the authorities.

British Chamber of Commerce.—We would draw the attention of manufacturers and merchants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appointing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual subscription is merely the nominal one of £1. The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber. Home enquires can obtain further particulars from our London office,'36, New'Broad-street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

The Rev. Roland Wormell assisted, and more than 70 boys and girls spent a most enjoyable afternoon. After partaking of a sumptuous tea, which was provided by Mr. G. B. Alderson, they all adjourned to the lawn, where they disported themselves in all manner of games and races, egg-spoon race, three legged race, tug of war, boys versus girls, etc., for which numerous prize were given, and presented by Mrs. Anastas to each winner. There was also a large number of consolation prizes, thereby making every little heart bright and happy. Several ladies and gentlemen were present to assist in entertaining the children. The proceedings terminated with hearty cheers for Mr. G? B. Alderson, Mr. and Mrs. Anastas, and the ladies and gentlemen who had assisted, and the singing of ‘God save the King” We may add that Mrs. Anastas deserves the thanks of all members of the Church of England in Alexandria for her seven years’ unceasing labours among the children of St. Mark’s Sunday School, whose appreciation of which is seen at a glance, whenever this kind-hearted lady is in their midst.

div.head: obituary.
M. HUMBERT EBANO.
div.p: ' It is with deep regret that we learn of the death on trie 10th inst. of M. Humbert Ebano, acting manager of the Stock Office of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo. He was an able, active, energetic official of the bank, and was held the highest esteem, as shown by the position of trust to which he had been promoted just before his illness. He had joined the bank from the very day of its foundation. We tender our most sincere condolence to his bereaved brother, and to his other relatives.

div.head: BAMLEH BATHING ACCIDENT
FUNERAL OF DECEASED OFFICERS.
div.p: At the inquest held on Saturday before Mr. F. G. Freeman, H.B.M’s Vice-Consul, at Ras el Tin hospital, it was proved that the sad accident, by which Captains Stokes and. Carey lost their lives, took place between 4.30 and 5.0 p.m, In his evidence Captain Crawley, A.S.C., stated that hearing a noise at about 5 p.m. he looked from the balcony ot the Beau Rivage Hotel and saw Capt. Carey swimming against the current, and making little or no progress Stokes having disappeared. Hearing him call for help Capt. Crawley ran to the beach, took his coat off, and went in getting to within five or six yards of the swimmer, when the current carried him away to the east. He made a second attempt, this time with a rope, and was himself carried under, and had to be hauled ashore, when Capt. Carey had disap-peared. The other evidence dealt mainly with the attempts at restoring animation in the ease of Capt. Carey, which appear to have been persevered with as long as there was any hope. The jury which consisted of Messrs. J. T. Atkin, J. Gunn, and C. D. Stacey gave a verdict in accordance with the evidence, and recorded their hearty commendation of Capt. Crawley’s courageous attempt at a rescue.

At 5 p.m. on Saturday the military funeral started from the Bourse. Shortly before that hour a strong detachment of the 2nd Royal Inniskillking Fusiliers had,arrived by special train from Cairo, and marched to the square, where it was mot by the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment, ‘i he procession was preceded by the Egyptian mounted police, who kept the streets clear as far as the Rosetta gate. The military mounted police led the long column, followed by the band of the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment, which played the Dead March. The two gun carriages, which conveyed the bodies to their resting place were draped with the Union Jack, and we were glad to note that almost all the Europeans and Syrians who were present— and the cortege passed through crowded streets —sainted the dead. General Bullock, Maj. Ludlow.D.A.A.G., Admiral Sir R M. Blomfield, and several of the principal members of the Head Quarters staff, representatives of the Governorat and the Egyptian Army, and severa! Well known members of the Consular Body and the British community followed. The Iunis-killings detachment, and the 2nd Royal Berkshires brought up the rear. At the Rosetta gate the procession was joined by the firing party, and the two bands of the Inniskillings who played the Dead March as far as the cemetery. The Rev. A. H. Manning, acting-Chaplain to the forces, conducted the burial service by the grave, where a number of beautiful wreaths had been laid by the comrades and friends of the deceased. The coffins were carried into the cemetery by the. sergeants and staff sergeants of the Inniskiliing Fusiliers. On the conclusions of the burial service, the usual volleys were fired over the grave, and the general salute to the dead, and the "Last Post” brought the sad ceremony to an end

The following special army order has been issued from the Headquarters, Cairo ‘It is with profound regret that the General Officer Commanding announces the deaths of Captain E. S. Carey, Adjutant, 2nd Bn. Royal Innis-killing Fusiliers and of Captain C. H. G. V. Stokes, 2nd Bn Royal Inniskiliing Fusiliers, who were accidentally drowned while bathing at Alexandria on 11th August. Both these Officers did distinguished service during the late war, and the Server sustains a great loss by their untimely
THE HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE.

We mentioned in a recent issue that the above company, which has taken Over the business of Mr. Stangen, the well known German tourist agent, contemplated starting a river passenger service between Cairo and Assouan during the tourist season of 1906-7, to compete with the old established lines of Messrs. Cook and Son, and the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company. Later it was announced that negotiations had been to entered into between the latte and the Hamburg-Amerika Company to work the two services in conjunction. It appears, from what we now learn, that the negotiations between the two companies are still in progress, and there is every reason to believe that a satisfactory arrangement will be arrived at sood. Several meetings have already taken place in Europe between the representatives of both sides, but nothing definite has yet been decided.

div.head: CONSTANTINOPLE OUTRAGE
another Theory.
div.p: We have been shown a letter from a British resident in Constantinople which gives the following news of the bomb outrage against H.I.M. the Sultan. "in a country like this, where nothing in the shape of public meetings is allowed, interest,even in such an occurrence, dies down very quickly. It is, generally speak-ing, dangerous for an ordinary Turk to talk politics, excepting in the privacy of his own house, where, it is to be presumed, no members of the Khafieh are present. Consequently there has been no public display of indignation—or of approbation-and all that I get from peasants, boatmen, and the like, is—“We think it was an Armenian, but, please, may we change the subjeot ?” Preposterous stories were current about the extent of the casualties, many supposing that at least 1,000 persons were disposed of. As a matter of fact, I think, seventeen were killed and forty odd wonnded. The Saltan behaved quite coolly, realising that the danger to his person was passed, and keeping off the crowd of officers and ministers that gathered round him; as much, I fancy, from a desire to avoid another attack with cold steel, as to stop the panic. The police scoured the town, arrested several hundreds of harmless folk, and sent back to their homes as many Armenians and Bulgars not domiciled here, as they could find. They have, as yet, hit on no clue worth anything, though they got up a yam about an india-rubber tyred carriage, which has appeared in all the papers. Many of the best-informed residents think it more probable that the outrage was the work of plotters at the palace—perhaps of the Albanian body guard, who are terribly out of hand at present. Of course the revolutionaries, Armenians and Macedonians, took the “oredit” for a cruel and clumsy outrage, and the police are only too glad to be spared the trouble of ferreting about among the secretaries and chamberlains at Yildiz Kiosk, some of whom are disaffected scoundrels.”
SHOCKING SUICIDE IN CAIRO

A French gentleman, of the name of Emile Jullien, committed suicide yesterday morning by jumping from a third floor balcony into the street. He sustained frightful injuries to the head, and death was almost instantaneous. The deceased, who lived at the Maison Sabbagh, in the Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, with his brother and his family, had been suffering for over a year from melancholia which, at times, assumed an acute form. This was the case on Saturday night, when he was carefully watched. He ran twice to the balcony early in the morning with the intention of jumping over, and was prevented, hot the third time he succeeded in evading his watchers, and accomplished his purpose. The late Monsieur Emile Jullien was a batchelor of 39 years of age, and had formerly been employed at the local Mixed Tribunals.

div.head: The Nile FLOOD.
MR. WEBB’S Report
div.p: In my last note I pointed out the following, viz (a) that the levels of the river had been unprecedently low from the middle of May, and that the irrigation of the summer crops had only been rendered possible by the supplementary supply derived from the Assouan-Reservoir. (b) That the flood was very late in its earlier stages, and promised to be low.

The Assouan Reservoir was emptied on 20th July (one month later than in 1904), since which date the supply in the river has been maintained by the flood, which reached Assouan nearly one month later than the usual time, and then not in sufficient quantity to satisfy the demands for the irrigation of the “sharaki” durah lands as well as the cotton crops, so that it will be found necessary to maintain the canals in the Delta and Middle Egypt until probably the middle of this month.

The rice crop, has, naturally, suffered in many places, but the cotton crop has been entirely saved by the Assouan Reservoir. Both in the Delta and Middle Egypt it is stated to be most excellent, and unless unfavorable climatic conditions prevail in September next, the crop should be a record one. The Cotton worm has been practically extirpated, owing to the very energetic and successful measures organised by the Ministry of Interior.

The irrigation of the “sharaki" durah lands has been somewhat retarded, but is in advance of the years previous to the construction of the weir below the Delta Barrage and the Assiout Barrage : the delay has caused com plaint, bat it is doubtful if any real damage has been done. It may be noted that in 1899, the irrigation of “sharaki” durah lands was not allowed until the 6th August in the Delta, whilst in the present year it was allowed 10 days earlier. Owing to the rise now taking place the irrigation of all crops in the Delta and Middle Egypt is absolutely assured, and no further anxiety need be felt throughout the flood. Regulation is being carried on both at the Delta, Zifta and Assiout Barrages; the latter will be completely closed within the next few days.

It may interesting to note that op to date not a drop of water has passed down the two branches of the Nile into the sea. The “sadd” in the Rosetta branch, however, is not likely to stand more than a few days longer. This fact, alone, shows how very late the flood has been, and how usefuls the barrages have been in utilising every drop of water available.
At Khartoum.—The following table gives a comparison of the gauges at Khartoum tor 1905, last year, and the two very low years, 1899 and 1902, viz :—

It will be seen from the above that the levels are 1.50 metres below those of last year, which wan by no means a good year, and 25 to 30 centimetres below those of 1899 and 1902, both yearn of extremely low floods. The Hood In the While Nile has been fairly normal that it the Blue Nile completely failed. Captain Lyons, who has most skilfully and so entifically studied the question, states that there wan great deficiency in the rains in Abyssinia during May and June, that in July matters improved, and “that it seems probable that, so far as indications show, the August rains are more likely to be poor than good." The prospects therefore, are not promising,and although a rise has lately taken place on the Blue Nile and the Atbara, the present indication is that the flood of this year will follow that of 1902.
At Assouan.—The following table gives a comparison of the gauges at Assouan for 1905, last year, the very low years 1899 and 1902, as well as the average for the past 30 years.

div.p: Departures
Arrivals

From the above it will be seen that the Assouan gauge is now 2.74 metres below last year and 3.01 metres below the average of the last 30 years. Taking into consideration the rise south of Assouan, now taking place, it is probable that the flood of this year will follow that of 1902. According to the rules of the Public Works Ministry, a “bad Nile” is declared when the Assouan gauge does not reach 13 pics on the 15th August; as there is no possibility of this occurring, the Ministry has decided to declare a “bad Nile” at once, and instructions have been issued to take the same measures as were carried out to meet he low flood of 1902. The area of “sharaki” in 1902 was 128,000 feddana, and, unless conditions rapidly improve, it is quite probable that the same area may remain unirrigated by the present flood.

Summary —In the Delta and Middle Egypt the irrigation of all crops is assured by the Delta, Zifta and Asriont Barrages, though the durah crops must necessarily be late. In Upper Egypt the conditions are far from favorable and indicate a flood similar, if not inferior, to that of 1902.

div.head: Mariage
div.p: Le mariage de M. P. Drivas avec Mile L. Pisani a été célébré hier an New Khédivial Hotel suivant le rite grec-orthodoxe, en présence d’une foule de parents et d’amis. M. G. Zervudachi, conseiller municipal, remplissait les fonctions de parrain. Apres la bénédiction nuptiale les invités ont fait honneur à un buffet deçremier choix. Le bal qui a suivi était accompagné d’un excellent orchestre et pendant les intermèdes Mlles Fiteni ont exécutés sur le piano des morceaux délicieux à deux, quatre et six mams. Les cadeaux offerts aux, nouveaux mariés étaient nombreux et superbes.

div.head: M. de Saint-Bonnet
div.p: Nous avons le regret d’annoncer la mort de notre confrère, M. de Saint-Bonnet. Les circons-tances dans lesquelles le décès a eu lieu ne peuvent encore être précisées. Il semblerait toutefois que la mort a du être subite ét survenir samedi dans l’après-midi. le jour pré- cedent on avait vu le regretté défunt, comme naire, arroser les fleurs de son jardin attenant à la maison qu’il habitait seul près du Boulevard Bàb Sidra. Ge sont les voisins qai ne le voyant pas pas paraitrè'sâlon son habitude et sentant une une mauvaiseodeur émaner de son logement en informèrent hier à 3 heures de l’après-midi le chawiohe de garde. Celui-ci sa rendit après de langues tergiversations chez le mamour du caracol Attarine, qui, pour un motif qua nous ne comprenons pas, tefusa de tenir compte de cet avertissement. Ce n’est quaprè3 une nouvelle insistance du ohawiche de garde, pressé par les voisins, qu’il se décida vers 6 heures et demie à se rendre sur les lieux où il constata le fait de la mauvaise odeur, fit çlouer les volets et ordonna- d attendre les instructions du consulat de France. Le corps fut enlevé à 10 heures et demie seulement pour être transporté Â l'hôpital. Ce sont là dés faits qne nous avons cru devoir relater en détail pour en prévenir le retour. M. de St.-Bonnet s’occupait de publicité et était en correspondance avec plusieurs journaux d’Egypte et de France.

div.head: DERNIERE HEURE
div.p: (Clôture de la Bourse Khédiviale 1h. p.m.)
Cours de l’Association des Courtiers en Marchandises
Egyptian Prisons
COLES PASHA’S REPORT.
Judicial - (Continued).
Juvenile offenders.

In my report for 1903 1 drew attention to the fact that upwards of 4,000 boys had been imprisoned during the year, and I expressed a hope that with the revised code, such a record would never have to be made again. My hopes have been so far realised that during the year under report 2,399 juveniles only have been imprisoned, whilst 2,507 have been punished by whipping. I venture to think, .however, that there is still room for improvement in our dealings with juvenile offender, and that though Egyptian magistrates may perhaps be accused of leniency when punishing old offenders they can hardly be found' fault with for soft-heartedness, when administering justice to children.
Offences committed by juveniles.

In the present report I have been able to supply much more detailed information regard ing juvenile criminals than, in any previous report, and I have devoted two tables entirely to young criminals. In the first, offences com-mitted by juveniles are classified and the punishments awarded given, In the second, the classification shows the Courts that have dealt with such cases.
If we first examine the offences committed
and punishments awarded we find
Casos. Imprisoned. Whipped.
Contraventions 2,461 1,161 1,299
Assaults 1,165 518 647

The contraveners are many of them little shoe blacks without their regulation “number,” or boys leading about blind beggars in proscrib ed quarters. “Assault” means boys fighting md squabbling together, and the majority of the little thieves (judging from those sent to the Reformatory*) are first offenders. It is true that some of these children were imprisoned in default of payment of a fine, but unless a child's parents can be made to pay the fine, such a punishment means imprisonment for the child.
Boys cannot be sent to a Reformatory unless they have committed a crime or délit, and in the absence of any Industrial Schools, it is,

[ admit, very difficult for judges to deal with such cases, but I am convinced, that in many of them, a police prosecution is quite unnecessary, and out of such a large number of cases only 87 youthful offenders (see Judicial Adviser's Report) handed over to their parents a very small percentage.
Ju'venile crime - where committed.

The number of young delinquents sentenced has little or no connection with the population. For instance, Mehaila-el-Kubra is one of the largest town in Egypt, and yet 15 boys only were whipped and none imprisoned throughout the year. Mansonrah, too, has only 34 cases, whilst small villages like Dikurnis, Samalloot, Deshna, Itai-el-Barood have many more apparently than their share.
Juvenile courts.

The Ministry of Justice has lately established a juvenile court in Cairo and a special judge sits once a week to deal with youthful offenders, but personally I am rather doubtful whether this “tentative measure” will prove very efficacious. The fact that the judge only sits once a week is of itself a grave objection, as a sentence of whipping after a child has been several days in prison defeats the purpose for which whipping is recommended. This judge, too, can only deal with a small portion of the cases occurring in Egypt.

The problem is not easy of solution, but I am inclined to think that the remedy lies more with the Procureur General’s Department than with the Courts. A special Bureau dealing with juveniles, and a single member of the Parquet receiving daily reports of cases and children awaiting trial in prison throughout Egypt, will very soon check excessive zeal on the part of police, or carelessness, or neglect, on the part of the Parquet ; especially if all cases in which juveniles are concerned have precedence over ordinary cases, and judges know that want of appreciation of instructions on their part, will be heard of again. i may say that the Procureur General has already acted in the matter somewhat on these lines, and if his circular orders lately issued are obeyed by both Police and Parquet, we should see a considerable improvement daring the current year.
Industrial school.

What is really required, too, is a special law for the Waifs and Strays of the large towns and an establishment on the Reformatory model in which they can be, received. Parents are constantly asking me to take charge of unruly sous, and little homeless vagabonds have even come to me and asked to be admitted to the Reformatory. It is with great reluctance that they have been told that entrance to the Reformatory can only be gained through a Criminal Court.
If such a law be passed, and a school be provided in addition to the Reformatory, juveniles will very soon disappear from our prisons.
Labour in lieu of imprisonment.

We have seen that the number of persons imprisoned in default of payment of fine has largely decreased, owing to the revision of the law which now makes it less profitable to go to prison. For similar reasons, the number of persons who elected to labour in lieu of imprisonment has decreased from 61,728 in 1993 to 43,684 in 1904.
This decrease is the most, marked in the large towns or bandars, especially in Cairo and Alexandria.

Of the number who elected to work 92% completed their task, 1,168 or 3% failed to report themselves, and 2,301 or 4% failed to complete their task and were subsequently imprisoned. In 1903 the percentage were 93; 2; and 4 respectively.
(To be continued).
*Of the 1904 boys sent to Reformatory 80010 were first offenders.
IN THE Isles OF GREECE.

Of "many-gated Thebes,” there is little trace but broken potsherds ; at Chaerones nothing whatsoever butt fragments of the colossal lion which commemorated the valour of the Greeks who fell fighting against Philip of Macedon, in that lost battle which was “the beginning evil to all the Greeks.” Is it worth while to spend seven or eight hours in the train for this ? Some two-thirds of our number decide that it is, and depart for the Piaeus and Athens after a hurried breakfast. We who have chosen the better part, watch them start (with mutual feelings of superiority), and then go down to a more leisurely meal, after which we settle ourselves on deck. A more perfect morning it would be hard to ima gine. ‘ Sea-girt Salamis,” far astern, is a blue cloud on the horizon ; Athens is growing misty and unreal, the city of a dream ; but we keep the crest of the Acropolis in sight until we reach Cape Colonna, that classic headland (Sunium) which we have to play off against the ruins of Thebes. Here, on the edge of the high promontory, to which, 2,000 years ago, Plato came to meditate, twelve slender Doric columns stand out milk white against the azure of the sky. These are all that remain of the Temple of Pallas Athene, which, hallowing the “vestibule of Attica,” was visible from afar to the eager eyes of the homeward bound Athenian mariner. Hence, it was said, he could see the sunshine glittering on the Spear of the colossal statue of Athene, the site of which we saw yesterday on the Acropolis ; while from Athens, watchers could distinguish whether the vessels rounding Cape Sunium bore the white sails which told of victory, or the black, which signified defeat. It is very sad to be robbed of one’s illusions, bat the Greeks must have possessed either field-glasses equal to ours, or eyesight vastly better !

Colonna rounded, our course curves northward, and soon after lunch we are within sight of the Bay of Marathon—a scene which we feel with intense satisfaction to be far superior in historical value to the battlefield of Chæronea. It must be confessed that the savants on board are not in complete agreement as to the precise spot on which the great fight took place, and a lively argument ensues. What matter ? It is enough to know that some-where on the sands of that quiet bay the Persian host disembarked, and that somewhere amid the tangle of hills which guard it was the Athenian camp. A mile or so more to north. or south, what, after all, does it matter ? “The mountains look on Marathon,” and we too have looked, and beheld the scene of the Greeks most splendid triumph.

And now, through the golden afternoon, we glide softly along the Egripos Channel, with the mainland, fertile here and wooded—and rather like the Kyles of Rute—upon the left,and on the right the shores of Egripos, the classic Euboea. This beautiful island, ninety miles in length, is traversed by a mountain chain, a continuation of Pelion, and we pass a succession of wild; fantastic peaks; incredibly purple, impossibly blue. And in the midst of the island, dominating the whole—a vision of dazzling snow-white, flecked with shadows of brilliant cobalt—the splendid crest of Dirphe, more than 7,000 feet high, soars up into the,sky.

This day of leisure was to have seen many tasks accomplished, but it ends with letters still unwritten, books unread, work untouched. To drink in as much as possible of the beauty of earth, sky, and sea is the first and paramount duty. Tea-time has come and gone, and we have come to the narrow strait.
“Where Chalcis faces Aulis’ shore, And Aulis’ waters ebb and flow,”

Aulis, it may be explained, has four changes of the tide daily, which is not what one would expect in the Mediterranean, Soundings are taken, the anchor goes down, and the electric launch and ship’s boats are despatched to bring back the Theban band. At what precise spot they are to be picked up no one seems to know. One passenger, with more imagination than clearness of vision, announces that she has discovered the travellers encamped upon the shore, and recognised them by their Panama hats But, alas ! for the theory, the group is presently seen to disperse, and the Panama hats resolve themselves into a flock of goats ! Wherever they may be, our lost friends are not there.
Time passes. Seven o’clock comes,and with it the inspiriting bugle call which proclaims that the roast beef of old England awaits us, and in obedience to the sommons we go down and dine.
Eight o’olock, and we are on deck again in brilliant moonlight which turns prosaic masts and planks and spars into ebony and alabaster, and the quiet waters round us into
“Perilous seas in faery lands forlorn."

‘ What has become of the launch?” we ask each other ; and “What has happened to the Thebans is the question which begins to agitate anxious wives whose husbands are on shore. Towards nine o'clock they return. It is hardly fair for those who have not dined to be kept parleying with us who have, but they have to run in the gauntlet of a good deal of questioning. “ Tired ? Oh, no, thank yon, not at all. Accidents? No, nothing has gone wrong except a steward overboard, and he quite enjoyed his immersion. Thebes was most interesting, and the loveliest place you ever saw, and altogether to-day has been quite the best thing in the whole cruise.” We think the same, and so every one is pleased. And presently, while we turn in to dream of
“Summer isles of Eden lying . In dark purple spheres of sea.”
the Argonaut retraces her course southwards and, rounding the southern extremity of Euboes makes for the coast of Asia Minor

It is high noon when we reach Assos. The sunshine is fiercer than any we have felt as yet and the anchor clanks down into water which looks like solid turquoise —a curiousous opaque blue which changes in the shallows near the shore into transparent emerald. Turks in gorgeous raiment stand in rows upon the tiny landing-stage and survey the British tourists with that combination of interest and dignified calm which is to be seen only in the East.

An ancient writer, who possibly was fat and scant of breath, is supposed to have said : “If you wish to hasten your death, climb Assos !” No one can feel weary of life on this exquisite spring afternoon, but every,one obeys the injunction of Statonicus, and a long procession is soon toiling up the narrow and well-nigh perpendicular path which leads up to the crater of an extinct volcano, the summit of which the Greeks who colonized Assos chose, as was their wont everywhere, as a building site. Bright-hued, short-stalked flowers enamel the face of the cliff, and when at last,after a climb of nearly 800 feet, we arrive panting at the top we find the short, thymy grass, on which we fling ourselves to rest, full of tiny scarlet anemones, purple dwarf campanulas, and the creamy rock-rose.

Rains there are every where. Just below us is a mass of masonry projecting from the hill side, howing where the great fortified city wall once ran, and fragments of Doric columns strew the temple precincts,, where, amid the relics of by-gone gradeur, shaggy brown calves are grazing, herded by picturesque Turkish hoys, who,in spite of their Moslem creed, stand with evident gratification to be photographed. The sites of theatre and stos,agora, treasury,gymnasium,and the rest are all to be traced by the antiquary, but,after what we saw in Athens,they do not greatly impress the average intelligence. What alone is worth the climb, had it been twice as long, and twice as hot—twice as steep it could hardly have been — is the view from this rockfortress. which is celebrated as one of the finest sites in Asia Minor.

Standing, as we do, on the crest of the promontory, we can look down on two harbours—that on which we landed, and another, to which we shall presently descend by a less precipitous path, where the remains ot an ancient mole or jetty are still discernible. Opposite us, as we look south, lies Mitylene, “the noble and pleasant island of Lesbos,” as Tacitus called it, birthplace of “burning Sappho and on the left the coast line of the Troad treads away eastwards, and the snowy summit of the many-fonntained Ida rises cloud like into an unclouded sky. The prospect is such as to hold one spell-bound for a long time, but at last it becomes necessary, or at least advisable, to move on, and, leaving the Acropolis and its polygonal enclosing wall, we come to the Turkish village of Behram, which occupies a terrace on the south-east side of the cone. It is a bundle of white, windowless houses, grouped round a dilapidated mosque.

From this point the hill slopes gently down to the banks of a river, which our guide intro-duces as “divine Scamander,” but which, alas for his veracity, turns out to ' be only the Touzla, the ancient Satniœis, which Honor mentions as flowing past “high Pedassos.” There is very little water in it just now, but in winter it is doubtless a rushing torrent, and it is spanned by a fine old bridge.

All this side of the hill is dotted with sarcophagi—grim coffers of stone which make of this flowery, sun baked path a veritable “street of the tombs.' How many of us knew before, I wonder, what we are told by an omniscient member of the party respecting the origin of the term "sarcophagus?” The literal meaning of the word, it seems, is,“flesh-eating,” and, according to Pliny, the trachyte of which these tombs were made had the property of consuming or causing to waste away the bodies which they contained.

Another pause to enjoy the beauty and exquisite peace this fresh view, and the new turn our faces seawards again, this time skirting the other side of the Acropolis rock, and passing the old gateway by which St. Paul entered the city when on his last missionary journey, he came hither from Troas, walking across the headland, round which his companions sailed. In so leisurely a fashion do we make our way back that by the time we have reached the harbour and the waiting boats, the sun is dipping into the sea and the western sky is beginning to hang out pennons and streamers of flame-oolour, scarlet and rose.

Yonder to the south-east is Dikili, the little port at which, early to-morrow, some of us are to disembark for Pergamon. Tiny as it is, it nevertheless boasts a telegraph office, and a busy man who is enjoying a well-earned holiday remarks with some trepidation, “I told them at home that if I were wanted back in a hurry they might wire to Dikili, but (hopefully) I am sure they won’t know where it it!”

Once more evening has fallen, and we are back on the boat after a hot but delightful day at Mitylene. Time fails in which to tell of the morning’s sightseeing—of the climb to the in-avitable theatre—the modern cathedral, where we are shown a fine marble chair of untold antiquity brought from the ruined theatre, and displaying on one side a carven Sphinx, and on the other the twisted coils of Aescula-pius's snakes of the ancient citadel, now a Turkish fort, into which we are courteously welcomed by a benevolent old general wearing red slippers and medals galore. Nor can much be told of the afternoon, spent by a select and privileged few in exploring the town itself under the auspices of a great traveller who had lived in it, and knew its people well in buy-ing fascinating water-jars, and sampling strange drinks outside a cafe where flaneurs, red-fezzed and swarthy, sat and smoked the nargileh or pipe of peace. Strange that the word “Mitylene,” , which a week ago conveyed so little to onr ears, will henoeforward be sufficient to present to memory a bizarre, many-hued kaleidoscopic picture of Eastern life.

The party from Pergamon come in while we are drinking our after-dinner coffee, very proud of having visited one of the “Seven Churches,” very stiff and sore after-six hours of bumping in native carts. In comparing- our respective experiences the evening slips away and before the break of dawn we are in sight of Smyrna.
CAPTAIN KISHIWADA.

He was an officer of reserves, and had waited patiently for embarkation orders. In the meantime he had worked at the common task, the daily round, that of a stationer. Month after month clipped by, hot Kishiwada’s enthusiasm for active service was not rewarded. He spent his lunch hour over at the railway station, watching the troop-trains running through the flagged way. He waved to the truck loads of bluecoated infantry, and cheered when the children cheered. Then the day of all days came, and the envelope with orders for the front.

One morning I was riding down the main street of Yokohama and saw an officer of in fantry, a little sturdy, blue-uniformed man, and his face was all aglow like the rising sun of Nippon. A rickshaw man pulled up, lifted his mushroom straw hat, and bowed to the officer and offered him a ride. The officer was Captain Kishiwada, and when he rode off down the street the little girls followed, and then the little boys, and then the big girls and big boys, until half of Yokohamo seemed to be running after Captain Kishiwada’s rickshaw. Here and there the rickshaw pulled up while the Captain went into different shops. I presumed he was making purchases. While inside, the little Jap boys with soldier caps waved small flags and sang war songs, and when the Captain appeared again they cheered and shouted “Nippon Banzai” until they were hoarse.

Here was a nation with half a million troops at the front making a fuss over one solitary member of the force. It all looked so childish, Imagine an officer in London riding about the streets making calls and followed by a lot of street children hanging on to his cab. But was it all so childish ?

Then the rickshaw stopped outside a fancy goods shop, a little one-roomed place. After the Captain came ont I went in and made a purchase. Then I tried to find out who the Captain was. I said to the little proprietor :

"I hope the Captain has made a big order with you.” The little proprietor replied : “Oh, no. That was Captain Kishiwada, my brother. He is off to the front, and has just been saying good-bye to the different business people who are his friends. He is my brother.”

I asked the fancy goods man, why he, too, was not at the front, and the expression that came over his face was the most depressing I have ever seen. It was one of acute and intense disappointment. The fancy goods man bared his arm, and in very sad tones remarked, “You see that my arm is thin. It could not hold a sword. There is no chance for me. I cannot go to the front I am an invalid.” Then he turned away. The ordeal was too much for him. A little later he came hack to me, and with pride pointed down the road, where Captain Kishi-wada’s rickshaw was standing “Ah! but my brother is strong. I said to him when I bade him gopd-hye, “When yon strike for Nippon, strike a blow for me," and my brother will. I had another brother, on the staff of Nogi, bat he is dead. He was killed. Captain Kishiwada will not come back either. He will be killed too.” I came out of the shop and walked down the street. Over Kishiwada’s shop was a flag with a great, big, red sun on it, I thought over the fancy-goods man's words. I thought of the army that had business men on the General Staff, whose officers were plain business people, and whose officers were not ashamed of the fact. Then I thought of another army, and it almost made me sick thinking.

FLOWER FARMING.
AN AUSTRALIAN EXPERIMENT.

Although Nature has become largely replaced by Science in the manufacture of choice perfumes and essential oils, the demand for flowers for industrial purposes in various parts of the world is being steadily maintained, and in Europe and America flower farming is conducted on an extensive and remunerative scale. Yet in the countries of the Commonwealth, so rich in plants yielding delicious perfumes and valuable essential oils, little or nothing has been done, so far, to practically utilise the advantages thus afforded. Systematic flower farming is, says a Sidney correspondent, still in its experimental stages, and there exists an almost untouched field of illimitable extent at the command of those possessing the necessary capital and experience in the manufacture of perfumery and essential oils.

IN Australia the garden flowers of Europe and Asia, especially those emitting the richest fragrance, are found growing in unsurpassed luxuriance, many being obtainable nearly all the year round, their profusion and cheapness proving how easily they are reared. Several of the essential oils obtained from the leaves of native plants are really perfumes, and their chief use is in scenting soaps and other preparations. The quantities used are small, most of the plants being wild. Among the native perfume-yielding plants which remain un-utilised are several varieties of acacis, includ-ing a few which furnish a scented wood. The Acacia Farnesiana, which is largely cultivated in Italy and the South of Franoe—the well-known pomade, called “Cassia,” being produced by placing the sweet-scented flowers in melted mutton fat or olive oil, until the latter become impregnated with their odour—grows plentifully in many parts of New South Wales and other States ; and another species of acacia, familiarly known as the Golden Wattle, is equally useful as a perfume plant ; as is also the Native Laurel, or Mock Orange.

Among the plants from which sweet scented and other oils may be obtained are the Native Sassafras. Peppermint, Bloodwood, Blue Gum, Mountain Ash, White Gum, Ironbark, Woolly Butt, Spotted Gum, TallowWood, Messmate, Red Gum, Poplar Box, and other species of Eucalyptus ; Ridge Myrtle, Tea-tree, Native Peppermint, Dog-wood, and Turmeric. Practically, the number of native shrubs and trees in the Commonwealth capable of being utilised in the manufacture of perfumes and essential oils is without limit, and when the large quantities of either product, obtainable from compara-tively small proportions of bark or leaves, is taken into consideration, it will be seen that in this direction Australia possesses exceptional advantages for those possessing the requisite capital and experience to establish large and remunerative productive industries. It may a;lso be mentioned that the Olive, Castor Oil Plant, and Linseed grow luxuriantly in the Commonwealth, and are easily cultivated.

Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;

Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE est en vente dans les rues du Caire tous les soirs à 7 h.30, excepté les dimanches et jours férieés. Le journal est aussi en vente aux gares du Caire, d'Alexandrie, de Tantah, de Damanhour de Kafr-Zayat et de Zagazig. Prix numéro du jour, 1 P.T.
Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.

Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
